abstract: The company beat analysts’ forecast, in part because of the global success of the film “Alice in Wonderland.”
snippet: The company beat analysts’ forecast, in part because of the global success of the film “Alice in Wonderland.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company appears to be having some success in repairing its movie operation, but now its television business is springing a leak.

headline.main: Disney Movie Unit Drives Strong Results in Quarter
headline.print_headline: Disney Movie Unit Drives Strong Results in Quarter

abstract: Peter Chernin’s mogul bid, Disney results and the Vanity Fair iPad app in today’s media coverage.
snippet: Peter Chernin’s mogul bid, Disney results and the Vanity Fair iPad app in today’s media coverage.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from today’s New York Times:

abstract: A Nickelodeon Web site wins a Boston organization’s award for being the worst toy of the year.
snippet: A Nickelodeon Web site wins a Boston organization’s award for being the worst toy of the year.
lead_paragraph: Nickelodeon is the latest media company to land in the crosshairs of Campaign for a Commercial Free Childhood, a Boston-based group that keeps tabs on Big Media.

headline.main: ‘Worst Toy of the Year’ Goes to a Nickelodeon Web Site

abstract: The media investor Haim Saban said that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from The Walt Disney Company, and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.
snippet: The media investor Haim Saban said that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from The Walt Disney Company, and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.
lead_paragraph: The media investor Haim Saban said Wednesday that he had bought back the rights to his biggest franchise, “Power Rangers,” from The Walt Disney Company, and had licensed the show to Nickelodeon, the children’s cable channel owned by Viacom.

headline.main: Saban Reacquires ‘Power Rangers,’ Moves Show to Nickelodeon

byline.original: By Brian Stelter and Brooks Barnes

abstract: The game Web site failed to meet profit targets that were tied to half of the acquisition’s $700 million purchase price.
snippet: The game Web site failed to meet profit targets that were tied to half of the acquisition’s $700 million purchase price.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Club Penguin, the subscription-based online community acquired by the Walt Disney Company in 2007, has failed to meet profit targets that were tied to $350 million in payouts to the Web site’s creators.

headline.main: Club Penguin Misses Goals, Giving Disney a Half-Price Deal
headline.print_headline: Club Penguin Misses Goals, Giving Disney a Half-Price Deal
